narrative: Rise from an outcast boy on the harsh Mongolian steppes to the architect of the largest contiguous empire in human history. Discover how Genghis Khan united warring tribes, revolutionized warfare, and connected East and West through the Pax Mongolica.

slides.title: Temujin: The Outcast Survivor
slides.content: Born clutching a blood clot, Temujin was abandoned by his clan after his father's death and forced to survive in the wild. These brutal early years on the frozen steppes forged the iron will that would later conquer the world.
slides.imagePrompt: Cinematic wide shot of a young Mongol boy standing alone on a snowy, vast Mongolian steppe at twilight, wearing tattered furs, holding a primitive wooden bow, dramatic lighting emphasizing isolation and resilience, photorealistic 8k resolution.

slides.title: Rise of the Universal Ruler
slides.content: Through charisma, alliance-building, and military prowess, Temujin united the fractured Mongol tribes. In 1206, a great council known as a Kurultai bestowed upon him the title Genghis Khan, meaning 'Universal Ruler'.
slides.imagePrompt: A grand gathering of Mongol warriors and white yurts (gers) on a lush green plain, Genghis Khan standing on a raised wooden platform holding a nine-tailed spirit banner, tribal chieftains bowing, golden hour lighting, intricate historical costume detail.

slides.title: Masters of Horse Warfare
slides.content: The Mongol army was unstoppable, characterized by speed, discipline, and the deadly accuracy of mounted archers. They utilized a decimal organization system and innovative tactics like the feigned retreat to decimate larger armies.
slides.imagePrompt: Dynamic action painting of Mongol heavy cavalry charging, dust kicking up, soldiers wearing lamellar armor, horses in full gallop, contrasting against a blue sky.
slides.videoPrompt: A dynamic visualization showing a formation of Mongol horse archers galloping across a field, executing a 'Parthian shot' by turning backwards to fire arrows while riding away, with motion lines indicating speed and trajectory.

slides.title: Siege and Conquest
slides.content: Adapting quickly, the Mongols learned siege engineering to breach the fortified cities of China and Persia. They employed catapults, gunpowder bombs, and psychological warfare to topple empires that had stood for centuries.
slides.imagePrompt: Detailed illustration of Mongol warriors besieging a high-walled Chinese city, trebuchets launching stones in the background, smoke rising, intense action scene with arrows flying, historical accuracy regarding siege engines.

slides.title: Pax Mongolica: Connecting the World
slides.content: Under Genghis Khan's rule, the Silk Road became safe for travel, ushering in an era known as the Pax Mongolica. This stability allowed for an unprecedented exchange of goods, science, and culture between Europe and Asia.
slides.imagePrompt: A vibrant Silk Road trade caravan with camels carrying silk and spices, passing a Mongol guard post, diverse group of merchants from East and West conversing, sunset over a desert landscape, rich colors.

slides.title: The Mysterious End
slides.content: Genghis Khan died in 1227, having conquered more land than any ruler before him. To protect his final resting place, legend says the funeral escort killed anyone they encountered, and the location of his grave remains undiscovered to this day.
slides.imagePrompt: A solemn funeral procession moving through a misty, rocky mountain pass, soldiers on horseback, obscured figures in the fog, atmospheric and mysterious mood, dark and muted earth tones.
